question: Question_04
statement:
Define \emph{S} to be the set of all real numbers \emph{x} such that
\emph{exactly one} of the two series

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac{1}{2} \right)^k \quad\text{ and }\quad \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac{1}{2} \right)^k\end{align*}

converges. Write down (with justification) a simple expression for
\emph{S}, using interval notation and set operations such as $\cup$,
$\cap$ and / or -.
sols:
The first series

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x-\frac12\right)^k\end{align*} converges for all values
of \emph{x} such that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-1 < x-\frac12 < 1\end{align*} which we can rewrite as

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-1+\frac12 < x < 1+\frac12\end{align*} that is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-\frac12 < x < \frac32\end{align*}

The second series

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=1}^\infty \left(x+\frac12\right)^k\end{align*} converges for all values
of \emph{x} such that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-1 < x+\frac12 < 1\end{align*} which we can rewrite as

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-1-\frac12 < x < 1-\frac12\end{align*} that is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-\frac32 < x < \frac12\end{align*}

So values of \emph{x} in the interval (-1/2,3/2) will make the first
series converge and values in the interval (-3/2,1/2) will make the
second series converge. Hence the values of \emph{x} which make
\emph{exactly} one of the series convergent cannot be in the
intersection of these two intervals. We can now conclude that that the
set \emph{S} is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
S = \left( -\frac32, -\frac12\right] \cup \left[ \frac12, \frac32 \right)\end{align*}
hints:
The series

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} x^k\end{align*} converges for all values of \emph{x} between
-1 and 1.
